discussion.content: Bad cable at the level 3 layer??

questions.question_text:
An engineer is reviewing network logs on a management switch and discovers that, compared to previous reports, a large amount of traffic is coming from a particular node. Upon further investigation, the engineer determines traffic coming from the port in question is using points that indicate NAT is occurring somewhere downstream from that point. After conferring with another network manager, the team determines a user has added an unauthorized SOHO WLAN router to the network. Among the vulnerabilities that could result from such an action is the possibility of the user inadvertently connecting the LAN interface of the
SOHO router into the LAN port coming from the corporate network.
This configuration would MOST likely result in which of the following scenarios?

discussion.content: It has to be D. Evil twin connected to the intended network? On top of that they use the word inadvertently, meaning "unintentionally; without meaning to". Evil twin attack without meaning to makes no sense.

comments.content:
I feel like the real answer here is actually C, should be "Rogue access point". Where Evil twin would be considered a type of Rogue ap, but one that is not connected to the secure network.

D seems wrong from the sense that NAT doesn't need dhcp, but I would imagine a normal SOHO router plugged in would have both DHCP and NAT already enabled.

discussion.content: How likely is C? How likely is D? Can we get a percentage chance? Or is this just opinion?

choices.A: Excessive interface on the corporate LAN port
choices.D: Competing DHCP servers on a single LAN

questions.question_text:
An organization wants to improve its ability to detect infiltration of servers in a DMZ, IPS/IDS solutions are currently located on the edge between DMZ and
Untrust, and DMZ and Trust.
Which of the following can increase visibility inside the DMZ?

discussion.content:
Out of all answers provided, 'A' is the 'most correct one'.

...But I would recommend to read the article within the link below as it explains the need for defence in depth approach from the firewall perspective (i.e. utilising firewall protection from only one layer of the OSI stack is not deemed best practice for obvious reasons).

In a nutshell, if the organisation mentioned in the question has no layer 3 firewall between the trusted, DMZ and untrusted zones then placing a layer 7 firewall only partially solves the mission of intent (that of mitigating in the most effective and efficiently (within the allocated budget) way possible any potential threats).

Know Your Firewall: Layer 3 vs. Layer 7
https://www.twistlock.com/2018/10/23/know-firewall-layer-3-vs-layer-7/

questions.question_text: Which of the following tools would a network technician use to troubleshoot a span of single-mode fiber cable?

discussion.content: spectrum analyzers by themselves are not able to make cable and antenna measurements that require known signals, such as that from a tracking generator to be applied to a device or network under test to measure the output or response

Answer 'B' is correct, but the 'Optical Time Domain Reflectometer (OTDR)' (answer 'D') has also its uses.

'The Optical Time Domain Reflectometer (OTDR) is useful for testing the integrity of fiber optic cables. It can verify splice loss, measure length and find faults. The OTDR is also commonly used to create a "picture" of fiber optic cable when it is newly installed.'

https://www.thefoa.org/tech/ref/testing/OTDR/OTDR.html

That all said, technically, for fibre optics, its called a 'Fiber Optic Spectrum Analyzer.'

Answer is 'B' > '. Configure a firewall with UTM. '

Reason:

What is a UTM Firewall and Why You Need it
https://www.firewalls.com/what_is_utm_firewall
